keyTakeAways: The death toll from flooding in central and southeastern Mexico has risen to 44, with Mexico's El Universal reporting 48 deaths.

Floods caused by the remnants of Tropical Storm Raymond and Hurricane Priscilla have led to landslides and widespread damage across five states: Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosi.
Specific death counts include 18 in Veracruz, 16 in Hidalgo, 9 in Puebla, and 1 in Queretaro.
Dozens of people are still missing, and around 320,000 people have experienced power outages with at least 16,000 homes damaged.
President Claudia Sheinbaum activated the military for rescue operations and aid distribution, emphasizing national commitment to humanitarian support.
Photos show evacuations via life rafts, flooded homes, and rescue workers navigating waist-high waters, illustrating the severity of the crisis.
The heavy rains are attributed to remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which impacted western Mexico and contributed to the flooding in central and southeastern regions.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Torrential flooding in central and southeastern Mexico, driven by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, has caused at least 44 deaths and left dozens missing. The disaster affected five states — Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosi — with Veracruz recording 18 deaths, Hidalgo 16, Puebla 9, and Queretaro one. Mexico's El Universal reports a higher toll of 48 deaths, indicating possible underreporting. Around 320,000 people face power outages and 16,000 homes have been damaged. President Claudia Sheinbaum activated the military for rescue and aid operations, emphasizing national responsibility in emergency response. The event is part of a broader trend of extreme rainfall in Mexico, including record rains in June 2025, which may reflect worsening climate patterns.
title: Death toll from Mexico flooding rises to 44, dozens more missing
